para.emphasis: "Under Linux there are GUIs (graphical user interfaces), where you can point and click and drag, and hopefully get work done without first reading lots of documentation. The traditional Unix environment is a CLI (command line interface), where you type commands to tell the computer what to do. That is faster and more powerful, but requires finding out what the commands are." -- from manとは

listitem.para: このガイドによって基本的なGNU/Linuxのシェルにおけるコマンドに慣れることができるでしょう。
It is not intended to be a complete guide to the command line, just an introduction to complement Ubuntu's graphical tools.
全てのコマンドは太字で示されます。
入力するべきコマンドは"太字"で示されます。
All of the commands on this page are to be issued from a command prompt in a terminal.
Note that Linux is case sensitive. User, user, and USER are all different to Linux.

section.title: ターミナルを起動するには
section.para: ターミナルはApplications > Accessories > Terminalにあります。

section.title: sudo：root権限でコマンドを実行する際に前につけて使用します。

listitem.para: 自分のアカウントで所有しているディレクトリもしくはファイルを扱う際には、sudoコマンドと共に次に示されるコマンドのほとんどを使う必要があります。sudoに関する詳細は RootSudoにあります。

pwd: pwdコマンドによって自分がどのディレクトリにいることがわかります。 ( pwdとは"print working directory"ということです。). 例: デスクトップ ディレクトリで"pwd"を入力すると、"~/Desktop"と表示されます. Gnomeターミナルもこの情報をウィンドウのタイトルバーの中に表示します。例えば、このページの最初にあるスクリーンショットで確認できます。
ls: lsコマンドによって現在のディレクトリの中にどんなファイルがあるかわかります。オプションを付けることで、ファイルサイズ・作成日時・パーミッションなどが表示されます。例: "ls ~" によってホームディレクトリにあるファイルが表示されます。
cd: cd コマンドによってディレクトリを移ることができます。ターミナルを開いたとき、あなたはホームディレクトリにいます。そこから移動するにはcdコマンドを使う必要があります。例:
ルートディレクトリに変更するには、"cd /"と入力します。
ホームディレクトリに戻るには、ただ"cd"と入力するかもしくは"cd ~"と入力します。
一つ上の階層に移動するには"cd .."と入力します。
直前までいたディレクトリに戻るには、"cd -"と入力します。
複数の階層を一度に移る場合、移動先のディレクトリを絶対パスで入力するのがよい方法です。例えば、"cd /var/www"と入力することで/var以下にある/wwwというサブディレクトリに移動できます。また"cd ~/Desktop"と入力すると、ホームディレクトリ以下にあるデスクトップというサブディレクトリに移動できます。
cp: cpコマンドによってファイルをコピーすることができます。例: "cp file foo"と入力すると、 "file"の内容をコピーして"foo"という名前のファイルを作ります。しかし、 "file"は消去されたりしません。mvコマンドを使うと、コピー元のファイルは削除されます。しかしながら、cpコマンドは新しくコピーを作るだけでオリジナルに手が加えられることはありません。

mv: The mv command will move a file to a different location or will rename a file. Examples are as follows: "mv file foo" will rename the file "file" to "foo". "mv foo ~/Desktop" will move the file "foo" to your Desktop directory but will not rename it. You must specify a new file name to rename a file.
To save on typing, you can substitute '~' in place of the home directory.

Note that if you are using mv with sudo you will not be able to use the ~ shortcut, but will have to use the full pathnames to your files. This is because when you are working as root, ~ will refer to the root account's home directory, not your own.
rm: Use this command to remove or delete a file in your directory. It will not work on directories which have files in them (use rmdir instead).
mkdir: The mkdir command will allow you to create directories. Example: "mkdir music" will create a music directory.
man: The man command is used to show you the manual of other commands. Try "man man" to get the man page for man itself. See the " Man & Getting Help" section down the page for more information.

section.title: System Information Commands

listitem.para: df: The df command displays filesystem disk space usage for all partitions. " df -h" is probably the most useful - it uses megabytes (M) and gigabytes (G) instead of blocks to report. ( -h means "human-readable")
free: The free command displays the amount of free and used memory in the system. "free -m" will give the information using megabytes, which is probably most useful for current computers.
top: The top command displays information on your Linux system, running processes and system resources, including CPU, RAM & swap usage and total number of tasks being run. To exit top, press "q".

uname -a: The uname command with the -a option prints all system information, including machine name, kernel name & version, and a few other details. Most useful for checking which kernel you're using.
lsb_release -a: The lsb_release command with the -a option prints version information for the Linux release you're running, for example:

section.screen: user@computer:~$ lsb_release -a No LSB modules are available. Distributor ID: Ubuntu Description: Ubuntu 6.06 LTS Release: 6.06 Codename: dapper

listitem.para: ifconfig reports on your system's network interfaces.
"adduser newuser" command will create a new general user called "newuser" on your system, and to assign a password for the newuser account use "passwd newuser".

section.title: Options
section.para:
The default behavior for a command may usually be modified by adding a -- option to the command. The ls command for example has an
-s option so that "ls -s" will include file sizes in the listing. There is also a -h option to get those sizes in a "human readable" format.

Options can be grouped in clusters so "ls -sh" is exactly the same command as "ls -s -h". Most options have a long version, prefixed with two dashes instead of one, so even "ls --size --human-readable" is the same command.

section.title: "Man" and getting help
section.para: command--helpand man command are the two most important tools at the command line.

Virtually all commands understand the -h (or --help) option which will produce a short usage description of the command and it's options, then exit back to the command prompt. Try "man -h" or "man --help" to see this in action.

Every command and nearly every application in Linux will have a man (manual) file, so finding them is as simple as typing "man "command"" to bring up a longer manual entry for the specified command. For example, "man mv" will bring up the mv (Move) manual.
Move up and down the man file with the arrow keys, and quit back to the command prompt with "q".
"man man" will bring up the manual entry for the man command, which is a good place to start!
"man intro" is especially useful - it displays the "Introduction to user commands" which is a well-written, fairly brief introduction to the Linux command line.
There are also info pages, which are generally more in-depth than man pages. Try "info info" for the introduction to info pages.

section.title: Searching for man files
section.para: If you aren't sure which command or application you need to use, you can try searching the man files.

listitem.para: man -k foo will search the man files for foo. Try "man -k nautilus" to see how this works.

Note that this is the same as the
apropos command.
man -f foo searches only the titles of your system's man files. Try "man -f gnome", for example.

This is the same as the
whatis command.

section.title: Pasting in commands
section.para: Often, you will be referred to instructions that require commands to be pasted into the terminal. You might be wondering why the text you've copied from a web page using ctrl+C won't paste in with ctrl+V. Surely you don't have to type in all those nasty commands and filenames? Relax. Middle Button Click on your mouse (both buttons simultaneously on a two-button mouse) or Right Click and select Paste from the menu.
